title: New laws could tackle $5.7 billion problem for millions of Aussies
text:
Laws being tabled in Parliament today that force employers to pay super at the same time as wages could save Aussie workers up to $5.7 billion in unpaid super.

Current legislation only requires super to be paid to employees every quarter, which lobbying groups argue cost Aussies $110 million a week and leaves some people $30,000 worse off upon retirement.

Should the laws pass, they will come into effect on July 1 next year, and supporters of the laws say it will allow Aussies to better track their super, and decrease the chances of it being lost due to the actions and fates of businesses.

Aussies could be missing out on millions a week in unpaid super. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"It's really difficult for employees to keep track of whether their employers are up to date with super payments when they're only paid quarterly, especially if their pay varies each week," Mary Delahunty from ASFA, a superannuation body, said.

"It means going through months of payslips, adding up the super payments, and cross checking them against their super accounts.

"Often, by the time an employee discovers they've been underpaid, the employer is insolvent, or unreachable, making it impossible to recover what they're owed."

Unpaid super could then unfairly impact certain groups of the working population, including women and younger workers.

Super Members Council CEO Misha Schubert said the reforms are simple and will benefit millions of Aussies who need it most.

"Payday super is a simple, fair and urgent reform to help ensure every dollar owed to workers makes it into their super account on time and in full," she said. "Millions of Australians cannot afford to wait."

"Payday super is also tipped to deliver an average of an extra $7700 for working Australians by retirement because being paid your super sooner helps to grow your retirement savings faster."

title: Record gold price to make Australia $60 billion richer
text:
T﻿he record high price of gold is forecast to be a shot in the arm for Australia's minerals industries as well as the wider economy.

This week the price of the precious metal broke through the $US4000 ($6071) barrier ﻿for the first time after surging more than 50 per cent over past months.

The spot gold price continued to rise in the US on Wednesday (Thursday AEST)﻿, hitting $US4044.05 an ounce in late trading.

The record gold price is forecast to offset a dip in mining profits. (Getty)

Gold is regarded as an ultra defensive investment choice during periods of economic turbulence and inflation worries.﻿

The Australian government is forecasting record prices will help offset a dip in mining profits.

High prices and rising export volumes are tipped to push gold earnings to $60 billion in the 2025-26 financial year, analysis by the Department of Industry, Science and Resources ﻿shows.

This will partly offset the impact of weaker-than-expected LNG prices this financial year.

Minister for Resources Madeleine King said gold and critical minerals, such as lithium, will help shield the resources industry against falling prices for some commodities.

"The discovery of gold helped build this nation and gold mining is still creating wealth and jobs for our economy today," she said.

Unusually, both the gold price and US shares have surged over past weeks. (AP)

﻿Gold and stocks both moving higher

This year's gains for the precious metal are historic, surpassing prior turbulent periods such as after the September 11 terror attacks, the 2008 financial meltdown or even the pandemic.

Gold is up 54 per cent so far this year, on track for its best year since 1979, according to FactSet.

Keep in mind that was a time when the US was grappling with double-digit inflation and a full-blown energy crisis.

What's unusual about today's gold spike is that it's coming in tandem with a booming US stock market.

Captivated by the potential of artificial intelligence, investors have piled into a handful of big tech companies that are carrying the entire stock market higher.

"The stock market and gold are marching to the beat of two very different drummers," David Kotok, co-founder of investment firm Cumberland Advisors, said.

'Surging global demand'

The gold rally reflects unease about the economy and lingering concerns about inflation, which has been stuck above the US Federal Reserve's 2 per cent target for the past four and a half years.

The US has hiked tariffs to the highest level since the Great Depression, and Japan's incoming prime minister has endorsed lower interest rates and higher borrowing.

Gold has surged 5 per cent so far this month as the US government shutdown leaves investors and Fed officials in the dark about the state of the economy by derailing major economic reports.

Against this backdrop, investors are piling into an asset that isn't linked to a single government: gold.

One of the biggest drivers of the rally in gold is the fact that the US dollar is having one of its worst years in decades.

The dollar's weakness has investors questioning the greenback's long-held status as a global safe haven.

Central banks around the world are also piling into gold.

This gained traction after Washington and allies punished Russia for its invasion of Ukraine by freezing Moscow's assets held in the United States.

Those sanctions raised further questions among foreign officials about where to keep their money.

Goldman Sachs told clients this week gold will likely hit $US4900 by the end of next year.

The Wall Street bank cited strong buying from central bankers, retail investors and looming rate cuts from the Fed.

Ken Griffin, the hedge fund billionaire who backed Trump in the last election, told Bloomberg this week it's "really concerning" that investors are starting to see gold as a safer bet than the US dollar.

title: 'So angry': Pauline Hanson calls for return of plastic shopping bags
text:
One Nation Senator Pauline Hanson has called for major supermarkets to bring back plastic bags, despite them being banned across the country.

The Queensland senator posted a video to her social media pages, which showed her holding a broken Woolworths paper bag with some items inside.

In the video, Hanson claimed the bags were of poor quality, and expressed frustration at the 25c it costs to buy them at Woolworths.

In the video, Hanson held a broken paper shopping bag from Woolworths. (Facebook/Pauline Hanson )

"You buy these cheap, rubbish bags that split and break on you all the time," she said.

"I'm over it, I'm so angry about this.

"And 25c a bag!"

She also called for the return of plastic bags to major supermarkets, writing: "Bring back the trusty plastic bags."

Plastic bag ban decisions are made by states and territories instead of the federal government, but every state and territory has now banned lightweight plastic bags.

Coles and Woolworths also voluntarily got rid of plastic bags in 2018, charging a small sum for shoppers to use reusable bags.

However, Hanson claimed such a charge in a cost-of-living crisis was unfair on Australians.

"You charge a fortune for it, cost of living, people can't afford it, and it's ridiculous," she said.

"I'm sure you're making a fortune out of it."

Woolworths has been contacted for comment.

title: Living legend becomes soccer's first billionaire
text:
Portuguese soccer superstar Cristiano Ronaldo has become the sport's first ever billionaire player following a contract he signed with Al Nassr earlier this year, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index .

Although the former Real Madrid, Manchester United, and Juventus star – now in the latter stages of his playing career – has always been one of the top earners in soccer, it's his current stint at Saudi Arabian club Al Nassr that has catapulted him onto the exclusive list of billionaire athletes.

After moving to the Saudi Pro League in January 2023, he became the highest-paid player in the sport's history with an annual salary of around US$200 million ($303.5 million), according to Saudi state media.

Cristiano Ronaldo has reportedly become soccer's first billionaire. (Al Nassr FC via Getty Images)

And in June 2025, the 40-year-old signed a new two-year deal with the Saudi outfit, reportedly worth more than US$400 million ($607.1 million) in tax free earnings.

That contract has boosted Ronaldo's net worth up to US$1.4 billion ($2.12 billion), according to Bloomberg.

The Portuguese superstar's earnings aren't the only stream of income that have skyrocketed his net worth.

Ronaldo has spoken of club ownership. (Getty)

The five-time Ballon d'Or winner signed a decade-long Nike deal worth almost US$18 million ($27.3 million) a year, as well as sponsorships with brands such as Armani and Castrol – adding over US$175 million ($265.6 million) to his net worth, according to Bloomberg.

Ronaldo has also amassed a global real estate portfolio and invested in a number of businesses in multiple countries, including Portugal and Spain.

The five-time Champions League winner now joins the likes of basketball legend Michael Jordan and retired tennis superstar Roger Federer on the sought-after list of billionaire athletes.

Legendary basketballer Michael Jordan is one of sport's few billionaires. (AP)

The latter mainly earned the status from a stake in Swiss sportswear brand On as part of a sponsorship deal.

Jordan, however, made much of his fortune from longtime endorsement deals with Nike as well as having owned a majority stake in the NBA's Charlotte Hornets up until 2023.

As the soccer superstar approaches retirement, club ownership is something that he has teased in the past.

"If I can be a club owner, why would I be a manager, sporting director or CEO?" Ronaldo said in an interview with Portuguese television channel Canal 11 earlier this year.

"This is my dream and I'm sure I'll get there. I'll even say more: I hope to not only have one club but to own several clubs."

title: Dolly Parton, in full glam, puts rumours about her health to rest
text:
Dolly Parton wants everyone know she's fine and "not dying."

An odd thing to have to say, yes. But the country music icon, actress, activist and humanitarian posted a video to social media on Wednesday to clear up rumours that had been going around to the contrary.

"I wanted to say, I know lately everybody thinks that I'm sicker than I am," Parton, 79, said in the video from a set where she was filming a commercial for the Grand Ole Opry. "Do I look sick to you? I'm workin' hard here."

Dolly Parton shares new video on social media with health update after concern over her condition (Instagram/Dolly Parton)

Dressed in a red and black fringe top, the "9 to 5" star added that she "wanted to put everybody's mind at ease" because many seemed "real concerned, which I appreciate."

"And I appreciate your prayers because I'm a person of faith. I can always use the prayers for anything and everything, but I want you to know that I'm ok," she added in the video, which was captioned "I ain't dead yet!"

Parton went on to acknowledge that she's had "some problems" health-wise, which she had mentioned last month when she cancelled a series of December concerts in Las Vegas. She then elaborated on the reasons behind those issues.

"Back when my husband Carl was very sick – that was for a long time – and then when he passed, I didn't take care of myself," she said. "So I let a lot of things go that I should have been taking care of. So, anyway, when I got around to it, the doctor said 'We need to take care of this, we need to take care of that.' Nothing major, but I did have to cancel some things so I could be closer to home."

Parton's husband of nearly 60 years Carl Dean died in March.

Heightened concerns about Parton's health were spurred on Tuesday, when her sister Freida posted to Facebook that she'd been "up all night praying" for the "Jolene" singer.

Dolly Parton is seen on Dolly Parton's Pet Gala in Nashville, on January 30. (Jon Morgan/CBS/Getty Images via CNN Newsource)

"Many of you know she hasn't been feeling her best lately. I truly believe in the power of prayer, and I have been lead to ask all of the world that loves her to be prayer warriors and pray with me," Freida Parton's post read. "She's strong, she's loved, and with all the prayers being lifted for her, I know in my heart she's going to be just fine. Godspeed, my sissy Dolly. We all love you!"

Mass panic ensued, reasonably.

But someone apparently had words with Freida, because she went back on Facebook later to tell everyone that she didn't intend for her words to spark worry. "I didn't mean to scare anyone or make it sound so serious when asking for prayers for Dolly," she wrote. "It was nothing more than a little sister asking for prayers for her big sister."

Later, another Parton sister appeared. This one was named Stella. "My sister Freida is always concerned when one of her siblings isn't feeling well so she ask for prayers on Dolly's behalf," she explained. She then went on to say she was mad about being asked for health updates on her sister.

READ MORE: ﻿ Cargo door on Jetstar flight wide open as plane readies for takeoff

Dolly Parton's statement cancelling recent shows also sparked concerns. (Instagram/@dollyparton)

Fans were on particularly high alert because this call for prayers came soon after the death of Parton's husband. The death of a long-term spouse has been associated with illness and even death in the surviving partner.

Late last month, Parton announced that she was postponing her December concerts in Las Vegas due to some "health challenges."

She added that she had been told by doctors she had to undergo "a few procedures," without elaborating further.

"Given this, I am not going to be able to rehearse and put together the show that I want you to see, and the show that you deserve to see," she wrote at the time.

READ MORE: Man charged after fatal shooting while hunting on NSW property

Dolly Parton performs during the college football game between the Georgia Bulldogs and the Tennessee Volunteers on November 18, 2023. (Icon Sportswire via Getty Images)

Parton was set to perform six shows at the Colosseum at Caesars Palace in December in her first Las Vegas residency in more than 30 years. Those concerts were rescheduled for September 2026.

Parton is one of the most-beloved musicians – likely even one of the most-beloved people – in the world.

She is a long-time best-selling songwriter and performer and actor. Her charitable works include helping underwrite Moderna's vaccine for COVID-19. Her program that sends books to children has changed an untold number of lives; the Louisville chapter alone noted recently that it had just mailed its 500,000th book to a child.

In her video on Wednesday, Parton said she hoped that if her admirers "heard it from me, you'd know that I was ok."

"I'm not ready to die yet. I don't think God is through with me and I ain't done workin'," she added. "So I love you for caring and keep praying for me."

title: Little-known bacteria causing increasing rates of potentially deadly infections
text:
A﻿ little-known strep bacteria is causing a growing number of potentially deadly infections and is disproportionately affecting Indigenous Australians .

Researchers at the Peter Doherty Institute for Infection and Immunity have studied infections of Streptococcus dysgalactiae subspecies equisimilis (SDSE), a close cousin of group A strep, and found it's rising at markedly different rates across parts of the country.

Both infections cause skin and soft tissue infections and, in severe cases, can invade the blood and organs and become life-threatening.

Group A streptococcus under the microscope. (Getty)

Lead author Dr Ouli Xie from the University of Melbourne said SDSE had previously been considered a "minor player" compared to group A strep, but the study proved it was causing "a significant and rising burden of severe disease in Australia".

He said in the remote northern regions, cases were 25 per cent higher than in the south-east.

Further to this, the study found that within the Top End, ﻿Indigenous Australians ﻿were three times more likely to develop the invasive disease than non-Indigenous people.

"We urgently need strategies that address the social determinants of health driving this burden, as well as new approaches to prevent and treat invasive strep infections," Doherty Institute researcher and co-lead author Professor Steven Tong said.

The study also found that some treatments used to control the spread of group A strep infections, such as antibiotics, were not as effective with SDSE.

The report, published in the Lancet Microbe , called for exploration of prevention strategies in vulnerable communities﻿, including the development of a vaccine.

title: 'Heart was jumping out of my chest﻿': Passengers look out window to see plane on fire
text:
A mechanical fault caused a plane engine to catch fire ﻿just moments after take-off, leading to operations at Adelaide Airport being temporarily shut down.

The Rex Airlines flight on the runway and was bound for Broken Hill just after 7am when the pilot braked and abandoned take-off.﻿

Passengers then spotted flames coming from the engine. ﻿

A mechanical fault caused a Rex Airlines plane wing to catch fire ﻿just moments before take-off, causing an emergency that temporarily shut down operations at a busy international airport. (Nine)

"The plane started to brake just before we rotated, and I thought 'oh that's not good', and then someone started yelling out 'fire, fire', and I thought 'oh that's not good either'," passenger Warwick Beverley said. ﻿

Beverley ﻿and his fiancé Sandy Holmes were desperate to head home after his emergency brain surgery to remove a tumour in Adelaide.

Today, they were left with "another story to tell". ﻿

Passengers and staff were ushered off the aircraft, and a bus picked them up from the airport and took them back to the terminal, where they were booked on another flight.

The fire self-extinguished. ﻿

Rex Airlines passenger Warwick Beverley. (Nine)

"I'm glad it wasn't in the air," Holmes said. ﻿

"I hate flying anyway so I had to really tell myself I was on the riverbank because my heart was jumping out of my chest﻿."

The situation impacted operations across the entire airport, with the runway closed for about 30 minutes before reopening about 8am. ﻿

Rex Airlines claims a small amount of unburnt fuel ignited in the engine's exhaust, causing the emergency. ﻿

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau is investigating the mechanical fault.

title: This 'snack' could make millions of unfit Aussies 'significantly' healthier
text:
There's a new snack that can make you healthier – but it's not something you eat.

A new report has revealed that quick and easy "exercise snacks" ﻿can significantly boost ﻿cardiorespiratory fitness in physically inactive adults.

It's good news for millions of Australians who currently fit that profile.

"Exercise snacks" ﻿can significantly boost ﻿cardiorespiratory fitness in physically inactive adults. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

So what are exercise snacks? ﻿

A report from ﻿the British Journal of Sports Medicine defined exercise snacks as bursts of moderate to vigorous physical activity lasting five minutes or less.

Examples include climbing stairs or lifting weights.

That five-minute period excludes warm-up, cool down, and recovery periods, and exercise snacks should be repeated at least twice a day, three to seven days a week.

The report analysed ﻿evidence from clinical trials across Australia, Canada, China and the UK and found that exercise snacks have a significant positive impact on inactive individuals' health.

The data showed that ﻿exercise snacks significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness in adults and could help counter the detrimental impacts of sitting for long periods of time.

Where Australia ranks in countries with the greatest health freedoms View Gallery

More than 80 per cent of people were able to stick to the habit for four to 12 weeks, suggesting exercise snacks may be easier to stick to than extended workout routines.

That may be especially true for individuals who are time-poor or lack motivation.

Almost 80 per cent of Aussie ﻿adults aged 18-64 don't perform sufficient physical activity, according to the ABS 2022 National Health Survey.

The survey defined sufficient physical activity as completing at least 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous activity across five or more days per week.

While exercise snacks alone are unlikely to make the millions of inactive Aussies hit that 150-minute goal, this research suggests they could help improve our nation's overall health.

READ MORE: Trump threatens no back pay for federal workers in shutdown

More than 80 per cent of people were able to stick to exercise snacks, which is promising for Aussies who lack motivation. (Getty)

The research isn't perfect, as it relied largely on existing data from varied and often experimental clinical trials.

But researchers concluded that exercise snacking is likely to boost the health of most ﻿physically inactive adults.

"The time-efficient nature of exercise snacks may help overcome common barriers to physical activity, such as perceived lack of time and low motivation," they said.

"Exercise snacks may enhance adherence to regular physical activity by providing short, flexible exercise bouts that are easier to integrate into daily routines."

title: RSL NSW bosses resign following ABC investigation
text:
The president of RSL NSW Mick Bainbridge has resigned from the board along with three other directors in a shock move made just minutes before a scheduled vote on his removal.

The announcement was made to the board on Thursday morning, 12 minutes before a planned meeting to decide whether Mr Bainbridge and fellow director Paul James should be forcefully removed.

In a joint letter to RSL District Councils, Mr Bainbridge, Mr James, and fellow directors Phillip Chin and Dr Charles New said their decision followed "serious concerns about governance, transparency and accountability".

Paul James has also resigned from his role as a director of NSW RSL. (Facebook)

"Given our concerns, which remain unaddressed, we do not believe that we can continue in our roles," they wrote.

Their resignations come after 7.30 revealed details of an internal investigation which alleged Mr Bainbridge and Mr James had breached the RSL NSW Board Charter, Code of Conduct, and Conflict of Interest Policy.

The confidential investigation and findings were the result of a year-long probe sparked by former RSL NSW chair Sophie Ray, whose complaint alleged Mr Bainbridge and Mr James, who also run a law firm together, failed to disclose multiple conflicts of interest, including their representation of a former RSL Lifecare volunteer in proceedings against the organisation.

Former RSL NSW chair Sophie Ray's complaint about Mr Bainbridge and Mr James sparked a year-long investigation. (ABC News)

RSL LifeCare is a sister charity to RSL NSW.

Ms Ray previously told 7.30 the RSL NSW board had been making crucial decisions about the RSL LifeCare board appointments and directors' remuneration, while Mr Bainbridge was even suggesting that RSL NSW should move to take over RSL LifeCare.

In June, the confidential probe upheld two of her claims, alleging the pair's actions did amount to a conflict of interest, and that as a result of this they "may have breached their professional obligations as lawyers".

Subsequent legal advice provided to the NSW RSL acting CEO advised that the RSL "may have a basis" to take disciplinary action against Mr Bainbridge and Mr James, including removal from the board as a result of the investigation's conflict of interest findings.

Mick Bainbridge, pictured left, became president of NSW RSL in 2023. (Facebook)

A joint meeting of the RSL NSW board and the District Presidents' Council had been scheduled for Thursday morning to vote on that action.

Mr Bainbridge and Mr James remain members of the RSL, and as such will be eligible to nominate for re-election to the board at the organisation's annual congress in October next year.

Mr James had also drafted a parliamentary bill for a new central trust to take control of millions of dollars in sub-branch assets.

The draft bill would enact legal change to allow the takeover without the need for consent or consultation from the sub-branches.

RSL NSW said in a statement that the decision of the four board members to resign "provides the organisation with an important opportunity to move forward with a renewed sense of unity, focus, and purpose in delivering our mission to support veterans and their families across New South Wales".

Watch 7.30, Mondays to Thursdays 7:30pm on ABC iview and ABC TV

title: A draft order to approve Hobart's stadium has been released. What's in it?
text:
Tasmania's parliamentarians have received a draft version of the order they will vote on to determine the fate of the Macquarie Point Stadium project.

The order lays out the conditions that the project must adhere to if it is greenlit to proceed by the parliament.

Most parliamentarians already know which way they will vote but some have been waiting to see the order.

The draft order cannot be amended by the parliament but the Liberal government can make tweaks before it is formally tabled.

The ABC has obtained a copy of the draft order.

What is in the order?

The order is broken down into seven parts, including Aboriginal heritage conditions, historic cultural heritage conditions, environmental conditions, TasWater conditions and council conditions.

Hobart's Macquarie stadium plan draws the 'experts' Photo shows Outline of stadium in Hobart seen from across the Derwent. Tasmania's minister responsible for the proposed $1.13 billion Macquarie Point stadium, Eric Abetz, says there are many "expert" views, but ultimately the government will decide.

There is also a section dedicated to the enforcement of those conditions and which agency is responsible for doing so.

The order is largely based on the draft permit conditions submitted by the Macquarie Point Development Corporation to the Tasmanian Planning Commission (TPC) in July during hearings into the project.

The order proposes the establishment of a design quality and integrity review panel that would consist of at least three members who would scrutinise the architecture, urban design and historic cultural heritage elements of the stadium.

The order proposes the creation of a panel to scrutinise the architecture and urban design of the stadium. (Supplied: Macquarie Point Development Corporation)

It also outlines the need for an operational management plan to be put in place at least 18 months before the stadium starts operating.

This requires an events management plan, which involves traffic changes, how buses will operate, and pedestrian access, along with security management, emergency evacuation planning and flood planning.

These matters can be addressed after the stadium is approved.

What happened to the legislation?

Before the snap state election the government introduced direct legislation for the stadium, but there was not time for it to pass.

The TPC released its final report advising that the plan be abandoned, but the government is continuing with the Project of State Significance process, which has resulted in this "order".

The legislation would have given Eric Abetz the power to amend the stadium permit. (ABC News: Kate Nickels)

The enabling legislation would have given power to the minister – in that case, Eric Abetz – to amend the stadium permit, as long as he consults with the premier, local council and regulators.

He would also have been able to direct the TPC to change planning schemes to match the stadium and to subdivide land and make changes to property arrangements "in the interests of efficiency".

Stadium report responds to TPC criticisms Photo shows A concept image of the proposed Hobart stadium at Macquarie Poi nt. The state government response to last month's scathing report from the planning commission says that while "change can be challenging", the "dream of a Tasmanian team representing our state in the AFL and AFLW is now within reach – we cannot turn back".

The order appears to lack these specific ministerial powers, but states that the director of the Environment Protection Authority (EPA) can sign off on certain changes.

The intent of the previous legislation and current order is the same — to get a stadium approved. The choice of mechanism is more a matter of timing than anything else.

Neither process was intended to allow appeals.

The TPC provided some comment on the government's proposed conditions, which are broadly similar to the draft order and are included as an appendix at the end of the full report.

"The panel does not consider that the proposed conditions address the full project scope and impact of the project, and considers that they do not mitigate significant negative effects, or give effect to all relevant planning considerations," the report said.

Loading...

Has it changed since the TPC report?

There has been a few updates.

A landscaping plan must consider ways to minimise wind impacts on patrons.

The lighting curfew could be extended for specific events with the government's approval.

A special events management plan could be established for events of up to 38,000 patrons.

There's also a requirement to manage coordination with events at the cenotaph.

Ride share services, such as Uber, might also be geoblocked near the stadium before and after events.

The draft order suggests rideshare services may be geoblocked near the stadium before and after events. (ABC News)

Can the order be changed?

Normal legislation is able to be amended as it makes its way through parliament, but the final order will be a "yes or no" proposition.

But the government has provided MPs with a draft order to enable some level of feedback and the potential for changes to be made before it comes to parliament.

This allows the government to choose whose feedback it might take on board and some votes will be more important to them than others.

The draft order will become a final order on October 22.

The governor then needs to approve it and the government intends to have it debated in the lower house on November 13.

The future of the project will be decided by a handful of independents. (ABC News: Sophie Jaggers)

When will the votes be cast?

Labor continues to support the stadium and the order will pass the lower house.

Who are the MLCs deciding the Hobart stadium's fate? Photo shows Six boxes showing names and photos of Tasmanian MLCs. The future of Tasmania's proposed Macquarie Point AFL stadium rests in the hands of the state's politicians. So who will vote which way, and what is the chance it will actually get up?

The crucial vote is in the upper house, where debate is set to take place on December 3 and 4.

With Labor's support the government needs the votes of three out of eight independents.

It could come down to independents Tania Rattray, Casey Hiscutt, Bec Thomas and Dean Harriss.

Premier Jeremy Rockliff intends to have the stadium approved by the end of the year.

It must start operating by the start of the men's AFL season in 2029 or government will face financial penalties from the AFL.

title: Gallery of tiny treasures joins global community
text:
A new art gallery in the WA regional city of Albany splits its exhibits across two levels, but unlike most galleries, it is less than a metre high and wide.

The Gallery of Tiny Treasures was the idea of local artist Jane Michael, who invites members of the community to take a piece and leave something of their own.

"It started because a friend of ours has a little library in town, just out the front of her house," she said.

"I thought we could do something different and have art instead of books."

The display includes postcards, small gel prints and metal works.

The only criteria for art to be included in the tiny gallery is it has to be happy. (ABC Great Southern: Rosemary Murphy)

"I thought it would be a way to help other artists have a bit of fun with it so they could do art swaps, and it's a good way to get kids involved too," Ms Michael said.

Global initiative

The tiny art gallery is part of a growing number of verge-side community installations around the world.

There are multiple websites dedicated to sharing them, such as the Worldwide Sidewalk Joy Map.

Rachael Harms Mahlandt started the map, which now has close to 500 listings, including Albany's tiny art gallery.

Rachael Harms Mahlandt started a toy dinosaur collection with her family. (Supplied: Rachael Harms Mahlandt)

Based in Portland in the US, she set up a toy dinosaur exchange outside her house after adventuring around the city with her kids to look at the various installations.

"We started telling people about the other spots around town and finally someone suggested a map," she said.

"For the first iteration of the map, it had about 24 spots and I already thought that was a really big number for one city.

"But after putting out the map, we heard about more spots in town and people got inspired to create one themselves."

Rachael Harms Mahlandt chose not to include pop up libraries on her map because there were existing lists. (Supplied: Rachael Harms Mahlandt)

Take a Shrek, leave a Shrek

Since launching the worldwide version last year, Ms Harms Mahlandt has received hundreds of submissions, some from as far as Finland, South Africa and New Zealand.

Ms Harms Mahlandt said there were some really creative ideas.

"Somebody near me has made their side yard, which they didn't use much … into a golf course that's just free for anybody to come by for a round of golf," she said.

"I am particularly fond of the plant and seed swaps; every time I see one I get excited."

Rachael Harms Mahlandt has released free designs so others can create their own mug libraries. (Supplied: Rachael Harms Mahlandt)

Others on list include puzzle libraries, mug exchanges and a Take a Shrek, Leave a Shrek box.

Back in Albany, Ms Michael is hopeful the tiny art gallery will be a permanent fixture where people can share and connect through art.

title: Despite $600m taxpayer bailout, Mount Isa's copper production not secure
text:
A $600 million bail-out package for the Mount Isa Copper Smelter may not be enough to guarantee its future, with a critical supplier to the facility still facing closure.

Swiss multinational Glencore received a financial bridging support package on Wednesday, all but ensuring the smelter would continue to operate until at least 2028.

But there is still a risk to its future.

Global explosives company Dyno Nobel announced last month it would cease operations at its fertiliser plant in September 2026 if a buyer was unable to be secured by March next year.

Glencore sites stay open with taxpayer funds Photo shows Sunset behind mining operation, candy cane coloured chimney The last Australian copper smelter processing third-party product will stay open after its owner accepted a support package.

The fertiliser plant at Phosphate Hill, 140 kilometres south-east of Mount Isa and its acid plant next to the Mount Isa Copper Smelter employ 500 people.

If a purchase cannot be facilitated, the Phosphate Hill facility would shut down, potentially also ending production at the copper smelter despite the taxpayer-funded rescue package.

The smelter relies on Dyno Nobel's acid plant, which supplies the fertiliser facility, to use the sulphur it creates.

The arrangement reduces the smelter's emissions, keeping it operating within regulations.

The Mount Isa Copper Smelter's future still hangs in the balance. (ABC News: Maddie Nixon)

No sale, no smelter

Dyno Nobel chief executive Mauro Neves said last month the company was working hard to find a buyer for Phosphate Hill, which has about 540 workers.

"Dyno Nobel is continuing to prioritise a sale of Phosphate Hill to a new owner and we have left no stone unturned in trying to secure economic natural gas as well as metallurgical gas from the Glencore smelter, both of which are necessary to attract and secure a buyer," he said.

Reacting to Mount Isa's copper smelter support package announcement, a Dyno Nobel spokesperson said it would continue to work with both governments to pursue a solution to the critical collaboration.

"Dyno Nobel is looking forward to engaging with Glencore over the coming weeks to understand the impact of the deal reached on its manufacturing operations at Phosphate Hill," the spokesperson said.

Dyno Nobel's Phosphate Hill mine in north-west Queensland. (Supplied: Dyno Nobel)

Federal Industry Minister Tim Ayres said the government considered the fertiliser operations as part of the country's economic resilience.

Mr Ayres said he met with Dyno Nobel representatives and described the issue as "complex".

"There is an interdependence between these facilities," Mr Ayres said.

"We've got a deal that secures the three years, but this is an important national effort that is squarely aimed at Phosphate Hill, the [acid plant facility] that is also in Mount Isa, the Townsville Refinery, but also the current junior miners.

"That's why we've acted to secure the smelter, but of course there is more work to do."

Optimistic of a solution

Glencore Australia head of corporate affairs Cass McCarthy said if Dyno Nobel was unable to find a buyer for the Phosphate Hill facility, the mining company could have other options.

She said the group was already conducting a study into ways to ensure the smelter survived.

"I'm optimistic that we'll be able to find a solution," she said.

A government bailout has been granted for Glencore's copper smelting production in north-west Queensland. (Background Briefing: Baz Ruddick)

"Certainly there is a co-dependency there between our copper smelter and [Phosphate Hill].

"I don't have a crystal ball, but what I would say is that the transformation study right now that we're looking at may identify other options."

Federal opposition leader Susan Ley has criticised the bailout package, saying it was a failure in economic and energy policy.

Ms Ley said it was a "band aid solution" and jobs and business would continue to be on the line.

title: Firefighter suffers serious injuries after being hit by falling tree
text:
A volunteer firefighter has been seriously injured while working to help control a bushfire on the New South Wales north coast.

Emergency crews were called to the site of the fire near Coutts Crossing at 5:15 pm on Wednesday, after a captain with the Rural Fire Service (RFS) was struck by a falling tree.

The man, aged in his 50s, was flown to Gold Coast University Hospital with injuries to his head, spine and pelvis.

Clarence Valley RFS operations manager Ian Smith said the volunteer was working on the fireground at the time.

"We were implementing about 4 or 5 kilometres of back-burning," Mr Smith said.

"During that time, a branch or a tree has come down and struck our volunteer in the head.

" Luckily, he was wearing a helmet. "

Mr Smith said the captain was based at Coffs Harbour and was working in an area where a fire briefly reached emergency level late last week.

"His wife was also on the fire line with him — she's also a deputy captain," he said.

"She's being accommodated up on the Gold Coast and being supported as much as we can."

More to come.

title: International football friendly moved amid immigration protests
text:
A football friendly between Argentina and Puerto Rico has been moved from Chicago to Florida due to the immigration crack down in the city, according to an Argentine Football Association executive.

The match was supposed to be played on October 13 at Soldier Field in Chicago but will be moved to Chase Stadium in Fort Lauderdale, the home stadium of Argentina and Inter Miami star Lionel Messi.

An Argentine Football Association executive told the Associated Press the match had to be moved because of the situation in Chicago, where US president Donald Trump had deployed the National Guard to quell protests.

The official spoke on condition of anonymity because the relocation had not been publicly announced.

Chicago Park District spokesman Luca Serra confirmed the match would not be played in Chicago but said it was a decision made by the promoter "due to low ticket sales".

No official statement has been released by the promoter.

The game has been moved away from Soldier Field to the Inter Miami home of Lionel Messi. (AP: Kamil Krzaczynski)

More than 1,000 immigrants have been arrested since the crack down began last month.

The Trump administration vowed to deploy National Guard troops as part of its push to boost deportations.

Argentina, the defending World Cup champion, will play Venezuela in another friendly match on Friday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami.

Messi has been called up to play in both matches, which are part of Argentina's preparations for next year's World Cup.

The cup will be co-hosted by the US, Mexico and Canada from June 11 to July 19.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AP

title: Sam Kerr back in Champions League, coming off the bench in Chelsea draw
text:
Matildas superstar Sam Kerr has returned to the Champions League but has failed to score a decisive goal after again coming off the bench for Chelsea.

Looking to be crowned a European champion, the one major club trophy that has eluded her, Kerr was given another 23 minutes off the bench but could not fire the Blues to victory.

They were forced to settle for a frustrating 1-1 draw at Dutch club Twente Enschede in their group opener.

Though coach Sonia Bompastor made seven changes to her line-up, she was still not prepared to throw Kerr into the starting XI, and the 32-year-old had to begin her fifth consecutive match on the bench.

For the fourth match in a row, with two hours of football now under her belt since her return from her 21-month lay-off with an ACL injury, Kerr did not find the net, with her only goal so far scored in her first comeback outing against Aston Villa last month.

Do you have a story idea about women in sport? Email us abcsport5050@your.abc.net.au

This was Kerr's first outing in the European tournament she so desperately wants to win since she scored against Swedish side Hacken in December 2023, a match that proved her last before she suffered the fateful injury on a training trip.

This time, she never seemed likely to grab a winner, after being brought on in the 73rd minute following Chelsea's equaliser from a penalty through Sandy Baltimore.

Twente skipper Danique Van Ginkel had struck in the 63rd minute against the run of play with a curling shot from the edge of the box, but French international Baltimore then converted from the spot after a foul by Lynn Groenewegen on Guro Reiten.

Kerr's latest cameo came after Matildas boss Joe Montemurro all but confirmed earlier this week that she would be involved in their upcoming friendlies in the UK against Wales and England.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Compatriot Ellie Carpenter, also likely to be called up by Montemurro later this week, played a full game for the Blues at right back, her first European outing since leaving France and eight-time tournament winners Lyon.

"We created a lot of opportunities and couldn't score more than one," Bompastor said.

"We had multiple situations in the box and 18 crosses, only six times we were first on the ball. This is not enough when you play a Champions League game."

Real Madrid had an easier time beating Roma 6-2 at home in the first week of the newly expanded league format, featuring 18 teams.

Manchester United, Atletico Madrid and Wolfsburg were also victorious.

Chelsea next faces London rivals Tottenham in a Women's Super League match, followed by a second Champions League game against Paris FC Féminines before the international break in the back half of October.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: 'Do I look sick to you?' Dolly Parton reassures fans after scare
text:
Dolly Parton has taken to social media to announce that she "ain't dead yet" amid public speculation about her health.

"There are just a lot of rumors flying around. But I figured if you heard it from me, you'd know that I was OK," the 79-year-old singer said in an Instagram video.

" I'm not ready to die yet. I don't think God is through with me — and I ain't done working. "

Parton's post, which appeared a number of her social media accounts, was captioned, "I ain't dead yet".

Late last month she postponed her first Las Vegas residency in 32 years due to "health challenges".

Parton was scheduled to perform six shows in Las Vegas in December, which would have overlapped with the National Finals Rodeo.

Loading Instagram content

The dates have been moved to September next year.

Parton did not provide specific details at the time, writing, "As many of you know, I have been dealing with some health challenges, and my doctors tell me that I must have a few procedures".

"As I joked with them, it must be time for my 100,000-mile check-up, although it's not the usual trip to see my plastic surgeon!" she wrote.

'Do I look sick to you?'

In the video clip shared on Wednesday, Parton is sitting on a set and speaking directly to camera, telling her audience that she is about to record a few commercials for the Grand Ole Opry, which is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year.

Dolly Parton's sister speaks out over singer's health concerns Photo shows Dolly Parton sister's post Dolly Parton's sister has asked fans to pray for the country music singer's health just one week after the star delayed several concerts in Las Vegas.

"Everyone thinks that I am sicker than I am," she says.

"Do I look sick to you? I'm working hard here.

"Anyway, I wanted to put everybody's mind at ease, those of you who seem to be real concerned, which I appreciate.

"And I appreciate your prayers because I'm a person of faith. I can always use the prayers for anything and everything."

On Tuesday, a Facebook posted shared by her sister, Freida Parton, escalated concerns about Parton's health when she wrote that she had been "up all night praying for my sister, Dolly."

Hours later, Freida followed up with another post.

"I want to clear something up. I didn't mean to scare anyone or make it sound so serious when asking for prayers for Dolly," she wrote.

"She's been a little under the weather and I simply asked for prayers because I believe so strongly in the power of prayer."

Dolly Parton's husband, who inspired Jolene, dies at 82 Photo shows Carl Dean kissing Dolly Parton on the cheek Carl Dean's flirtation with a bank teller gave his wife Dolly Parton the inspiration for one of her most iconic songs.

Parton offered her own clarification in the video, referencing her late husband of nearly 60 years Carl Dean, who died earlier this year at age 82.

"Back when my husband Carl was very sick, that was for a long time, and then when he passed, I didn't take care of myself," she said.

"So I let a lot of things go that I should've been taking care of.

"So anyway, when I got around to it, the doctor said, 'We need to take care of this, we need to take care of that.'

"Nothing major but I did have to cancel some things so I could be closer to home, closer to Vanderbilt, where I'm kind of having a few treatments here and there."

AP

title: Self-taught kid drummer makes dream debut with iconic rock band
text:
A boy's dream of playing with his musical heroes came true when Aussie rock legends The Living End invited him on stage.

Twelve-year-old Noah Pope, from Mogo on the New South Wales far south coast, was in the front row at the recent Wanderer Festival in nearby Pambula.

In a bold attempt to grab the attention of the iconic Australian rockers, Noah crafted a sign asking, "Can I drum with you?"

To his surprise, it worked after lead vocalist Chris Cheney spotted him in the 10,000-head crowd.

The Living End noticed Noah Pope had been holding up the sign for a long time. (Supplied: David Rogers Photography/Wanderer Festival)

"He said, 'I'll get back to you … I see you holding the sign. Your arms look very tired and you're as cute as a button,'" Noah said.

The Living End first formed in the 90s and is made up of members Chris Cheney, Scott Owen and Andy Strachan.

They performed as a headline act at the Wanderer Festival on October 5, which was the first stop on their tour to promote their new album, I Only Trust Rock n Roll.

Nearing the end of the set, the band brought Noah to the stage.

Lead vocalist Cheney admitted they had never invited a stranger to play with them before and were unsure about what to expect from Noah.

"The only people that have ever played with us are friends from other bands," he said.

"I'm thinking he's going to play a couple of bars of Johnny Be Good or an old blues tune that we'll just jam along to."

Chris Cheney is the guitarist and lead vocalist of The Living End. (Supplied: Wanderer Festival/Ruby Boland)

Instead, Noah wanted to play Prisoner of Society, one of The Living End's signature songs, and he pulled it off.

"That's a really tricky song to play … and he just bought the house down," Cheney said.

"He didn't just play the song, he played the heck out of it.

"It was such a euphoric, joyous moment for the crowd and for us."

Noah overcame his nerves in the moment.

"I just went for it," he said.

"It was a little scary at first, but when I got into it, I was just having fun."

A dream come true

Cheney said he and his bandmate Scott Owen were not much older than Noah when they first started playing.

"To have gotten up and played with a band like that would have been have been a dream come true for us," he said.

"I can put myself in his shoes, what it's like being a young musician and wanting to get on stage."

Chris Cheney invited Noah to the stage at the end of their set. (Supplied: Ruby Boland/Wanderer Festival)

Noah is a self-taught drummer, mostly learning from videos online over the past two-and-a-half years.

His drum kit is set up in his bedroom, which he has soundproofed with a bookshelf full of soft toys.

The 12-year-old is eager to meet other young musicians in his area who want to play punk music.

"I really don't have anyone to jam with," he said.

"There's not really any musicians at my school, so I'm hoping to find some at high school [next year]."

A bright future

Noah performed without in-ear monitors, which made it all the more impressive that he kept up with the band.

The founder of the Wanderer Festival, Simon Daly, took Noah and his mum backstage to meet the headline act after the set.

The band members were surprised to learn Noah was not in a band and was self-taught.

"This 12-year-old's never had a lesson and his very first band is The Living End," Mr Daly said.

"Just unbelievable, really."

Loading...

Cheney described Noah as "a prodigy", and the band's drummer Andy Strachan plans to stay in touch.

"They were actually going to help mentor me and help me with my career," Noah said.

"I was really shocked and actually cried.

"I really want to take it up as a job and become a little famous."

title: Measles cases from unknown source climbing in WA
text:
Authorities are urging people in Western Australia's Pilbara to be on alert for measles as the number of community transmission cases continues to climb.

It follows several identified cases with no known source.

An eighth infection was confirmed in the region on Wednesday, with 22 more exposure sites listed across South Hedland, Redbank, and Pegs Creek between September 20 and October 1.

One of the cases attended the Hedland Health Campus general ward on October 4 and the emergency department on October 6, but it is understood that the person was not a health worker.

The cluster takes the total number of cases to 47 in WA so far this year, nearing the state's worst outbreak since 2019.

One recent case was identified at the Hedland Health Campus. (ABC News: West Matteeussen)

Dr Simon Slota-Kan, a physician with the Pilbara Public Health Unit, described the spread as "unfortunate".

"These cases have not all been linked together very closely, like we usually like them to be, and we're concerned that there's now community spread," he said.

"Community spread means that this has been occurring and cases have been happening, but we haven't been able to say exactly [how] this person is linked to that particular person."

Previous cases have been traced to the Pilbara's largely fly-in, fly-out mining workforce, returning from destinations like Bali.

Dr Slota-Kan said the highly infectious nature of the virus made it especially challenging to track.

"It's very easy for people to spread it without themselves knowing and people coming in contact without them knowing," he said.

Several cases of measles with no known source have been confirmed in the Pilbara. (Supplied: WA Health)

WA Health has pledged additional staff and vaccine doses to combat the highly infectious virus in the Pilbara.

Dr Slota-Kan called on residents to monitor themselves for symptoms as schools look to return from holidays next week.

"That would be good preparation to check your vaccination status and make sure that you're vigilant for any cases, to protect the schools as kids come back," he said.

Testing sites are available at the Hedland Health Campus, Karratha Health Campus, Roebourne Hospital, Onslow Health Service, and Newman Health Service.

'Below the safe threshold'

What is the measles? Photo shows A boy with a third day measles rash. Australia was declared measles-free in 2014, but imported cases are still sometimes diagnosed. So, what does it do to your body, and what sort of threat can it pose to the population?

WA Health said the unknown cases had likely been introduced from travellers returning from overseas.

Measles was officially eliminated from Australia in 2014, but has resurged worldwide due to falling immunisation rates and pandemic-related disruptions.

"It really can only take one traveller to start an outbreak like we've seen in WA," said Milena Dalton, an immunologist at the Burnet Institute.

She urged anyone born during or after 1966 to ensure they have two documented doses of the measles vaccine.

Changes to vaccination standards in the 1990s mean many adults only have one dose.

"Australia has now fallen below the safe threshold, so we've dropped below the 95 [per cent] herd immunity level needed to stop outbreaks," Dr Dalton said.

"This gap is leaving thousands of people, especially babies, pregnant women and immunocompromised Australians, at risk."

title: 'Truly absurd': AC Milan star hits out at plan to play Serie A match in Perth
text:
AC Milan star Adrien Rabiot has condemned the idea of his club playing a Serie A match in Australia as "totally crazy" and "truly absurd", prompting the league's chief to scold the French international.

The decision to play a league match between Milan and Como in Perth in February, one reluctantly agreed to by European football's governing body UEFA, had already prompted plenty of criticism from fan groups, but the critique from Milan's own player caused more consternation in Italy on Wednesday.

"I was surprised when I learned that AC Milan will be playing a Serie A match against Como in Australia," Rabiot, the Milan midfielder, told French newspaper Le Figaro.

"It's totally crazy. But these are economic agreements to give the league more visibility, things that are beyond us. There's a lot of talk about schedules and player health, and this all seems truly absurd.

"It's crazy to travel so many miles for a match between two Italian teams in Australia. We have to adapt, as always."

The 30-year-old's outspoken criticism didn't go down well with Serie A chief executive Luigi De Siervo.

"Rabiot is right, we decide for him," De Siervo told Italian media.

Serie A game in Perth would have been laughable 10 years ago Photo shows AC Milan's Ricardo Kaka celebrates after scoring, looking up and pointing to the skies, in the rain Italian heavyweights AC Milan look set to play a match, for actual Serie A points, in Perth. What will the state government pay to lure them here, and why are some football supporters unhappy?

"He forgets that he is paid millions of euros to do a job — play football. He should respect the money he earns, and accept the wishes of his employer, Milan, who pushed to play this match abroad."

The continued fallout came as LaLiga confirmed on Wednesday that Villarreal and Barcelona will also play a regular-season league match in the United States on December 20 in Miami.

UEFA remains adamant these matches have been given "exceptional" approval and says the decision does not set a precedent.

"This match is a historic step that takes LaLiga and Spanish football to an all-new level," Spanish league president Javier Tebas said in a statement.

He and the league had been pushing for a regular-season game abroad for some time, with the first attempt coming in 2018 with a match between Barcelona and Girona, but the idea was dismissed after criticism from some players, fans and clubs.

Its subsequent attempts to play there also failed but the plan moved forward this time after UEFA gave consent for the game despite opposition from fan groups across the continent.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: De Minaur reaches 2025 milestone, into Shanghai Masters last eight
text:
World number seven Alex de Minaur has hailed the milestone 50th tour-level victory in his best-ever season as "amazing" after easing into the quarterfinals of the Shanghai Masters.

But now the Australian number four hopes his win — a 7-5, 6-2 victory over Portugal's Nuno Borges — is just a staging post on his way to what could be his first ATP Masters 1000 triumph.

De Minaur has gone this far six times at Masters in the past, reaching the semifinals and a final once each, but never claiming a crown, with Alexei Popyrin's 2024 Canadian Open win still the only Australian triumph since 2003.

De Minaur became the fourth Australian man ever and just the third men's player in 2025 to hit the 50-win mark, following Carlos Alcaraz (67) and Taylor Fritz (50), with the Sydneysider also leading the tour in 37 hardcourt victories for the season.

Kasatkina 'taps out' of 2025 Photo shows A close-up of Daria Kasatkina looking tired and sweating at Wimbledon. Daria Kasatkina ends her 2025 WTA season early, citing the hectic schedule and a high-stress year after switching nationalities to Australia from Russia.

The landmark never looked in doubt once de Minaur had earned the only break of the opening set to go ahead 6-5, starting a run of six straight games as he assumed total control in the second, eventually hitting 19 winners and making just 10 unforced errors over the course of an hour and 48 minutes.

It set up a last-eight date with 16th seed Daniil Medvedev, who outlasted Learner Tien 7-6(8/6), 6-7(1/7), 6-4.

De Minaur's season, with 50 wins and 18 losses, tops his previous best of 47-21 last year.

But he did earn two titles in 2024 and is aiming to match that by landing his second of 2025, following his triumph in Washington in August, with the draw looking a little more open after shock third-round losses for Jannik Sinner and Alex Zverev, and the absence of Carlos Alcaraz.

"For me, it just shows consistency and that is what I am most proud of," de Minaur said of his half-century.

"Showing up every single week, and it is an amazing number.

"I am hoping for many more to finish off the year and not stay at 50. It has been a successful trip to Asia so far."

The brutally hot and humid conditions in Shanghai have taken their toll, with Sinner retiring against Tallon Griekspoor with cramp while Novak Djokovic was sick on court during his win over Yannick Hanfmann.

"I told myself at the start of the week it was all going to be a big mental effort to go out there and compete," de Minaur said.

"I am happy to be in the quarterfinals and give myself another opportunity."

Medvedev struggled with cramp in his win. He kept telling his watching team, "I'm done", and looked at one point as if he was about to quit before he eventually prevailed after nearly 3 hours against US teen Tien, who beat him in another gruelling affair at the Australian Open in January.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

De Minaur will be facing his old Russian foe for the 12th time on Friday, with 29-year-old Medvedev leading their head-to-head 7-4 but "Demon" winning their only 2025 clash, in Monte Carlo, and four of their last seven.

The winner would then have a semifinal against the victor between 12th seed Félix Auger-Aliassime and Frenchman Arthur Rinderknech.

Canadian Auger-Aliassime outplayed Italy's Lorenzo Musetti 6-4, 6-2, while Rinderknech accounted for Czech Jiří Lehečka 6-3, 7-6(7/5).

Musetti's defeat is further good news for de Minaur as he eliminated the Australian in his only Masters semi this season, at Monte-Carlo, and they are direct rivals to grab a place in the eight-man ATP Finals in Turin.

The Italian is on 3,435 points in eighth place, 110 behind de Minaur in seventh. Auger-Aliassime has moved on to 2,905 points in 10th, with Briton Jack Draper, in ninth, already out for the season with injury.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

title: Live: Jamarra set to receive AFL lifeline as 'headscratcher' baffles Suns
text:
So this is a very interesting share from SEN's Sam Edmund.

This screenshot appears to show Zak Butters teeing off alongside Bombers duo Darcy Parish and Sam Durham.

Are the Dons replacing Zach with Zak? What are our thoughts?

Butters, like many Port players, absolutely LOVED Ken Hinkley. If Hinkley does take up a role with the Dons, which he is currently considering, expect to see these links heat up just a little more.
